popt4jlib.MinExplainSet

Class BottomUpMESSolver

  • java.lang.Object
    • popt4jlib.MinExplainSet.BaseMESSolver
      • popt4jlib.MinExplainSet.BottomUpMESSolver

  • public class BottomUpMESSolver
extends BaseMESSolver
    Bottom-up algorithm implementation for solving the Minimum Explaining Set (MES) problem. The MES problem can be described as follows: we are given a set of variables (items) X = {x_0, x_1, ..., x_(M-1)} and a set of instances D = {I_0, I_1,..., I_(d-1)} each of which contain subsets of the vars x_i. There is also a set of rules S = {r_0, r_1, ..., r_(k-1)}, each of which is both associated with a subset of X, and with a subset of D. It is assumed that for each I in D, there is at least one R in S that "satisfies" (or, "explains") I. The problem is to find a minimum cardinality set Y of variables x in X, that are sufficient to "explain" all the instances in D, in that for each I in D, there is at least one rule R in S that is associated with I, and whose variables are all in Y. Variables, rules, and instances are all identified by consecutive integer numbers starting at 0. Notice that in this implementation, the information about which variable is associated with what rule, is stored in a BoolVector, so that there is a _v2rA BoolVector[], and _v2rA[i] is a BoolVector containing those rule-ids that contain variable x_i. Similarly, the array BoolVector[] _r2vA is such that _r2vA[j] is the BoolVector containing the ids of those variables participating in rule r_j. And so on, for the BoolVector[] _r2iA, _i2rA arrays.

    Notice that in this implementation, it is assumed that ALL rules include the last variable (last bit), so all solutions assume -implicitly- that the last bit is set, but don't take it into account when constructing expanded solutions. The solution strategy is Breadth-First Search (with possible cut-offs in the new solution generation to limit the search.) Without any limits in the search process, the solution generated is guaranteed optimal; else it is necessarily a heuristic.

    Title: popt4jlib

    Description: A Parallel Meta-Heuristic Optimization Library in Java

    Copyright: Copyright (c) 2011-2020

    Company:

    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Ioannis T. Christou

    • Constructor Detail

      • BottomUpMESSolver

        public BottomUpMESSolver(int numVars,
                         int numRules,
                         int numInstances,
                         java.util.HashMap rule2vars,
                         java.util.HashMap rule2insts,
                         double minSatInstRatio,
                         int numvars2consider,
                         int maxqueuesize,
                         int maxnumvarsallowed)
        public constructor.
        Parameters:
        numVars - int the number of variables in this MES problem
        numRules - int the number of rules in this MES problem
        numInstances - int the number of instances in this MES problem
        rule2vars - Map<Integer ruleid, Set<Integer varid> >
        rule2insts - Map<Integer ruleid, Set<Integer instid> >
        minSatInstRatio - double the minimum required coverage ratio of instances satisfied by the returned solution over the total instances satisfied by all the rules
        numvars2consider - int the max number of top solutions added to the queue at every step (can be Integer.MAX_VALUE for no limit in the search)
        maxqueuesize - int maximum number of candidates to keep at any time (making it a BeamForming-Search) or -1 (the default, indicating no attempt to bound the outer-loop queue)
        maxnumvarsallowed - int default -1 (no limit) used to cut the search short

      • BottomUpMESSolver

        protected BottomUpMESSolver(BottomUpMESSolver svr)
        protected copy constructor is not part of the public API. Leaves the _K and _queue data members at their default values (0 and null respectively.)
        Parameters:
        svr - BottomUpMESSolver the object to copy from

    • Method Detail

      • solve

        public BoolVector solve(BoolVector cur_vars)
        the main class method. It can actually guarantee to find an optimal (least cardinality) solution that covers the required percentage of instances that can be covered by the rules, from the starting solution (that is normally empty), when the maxqueuesize variable in the object constructor is set to -1; otherwise, the queue size constraints can cause the search to miss out the truly optimal solution.
        Specified by:
        solve in class BaseMESSolver
        Parameters:
        cur_vars - BoolVector normally empty, but can be any set that we require to be present in the final solution
        Returns:
        BoolVector a minimal cardinality vector covering the requested percentage of instances that are coverable by the rules; may return null if no solution is found due to a low _K value set

      • solveContinuously

        public java.util.HashMap solveContinuously(BoolVector cur_vars)
                                    throws java.lang.Exception
        the second main class method. It produces all optimal sets of variables for any given length, from the starting solution (that is normally empty) upward until the entire set of instances is covered as much as the rule set allows.
        Parameters:
        cur_vars - BoolVector normally empty, but can be any set that we require to be present in the final solution
        Returns:
        HashMap // HashMap<Integer num_inst_covered, BoolVector vars> a map containing minimal cardinality sets of variables covering more and more of the instance set that can be covered.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • getMaxNumSatInsts

        public int getMaxNumSatInsts()
        get the total number of covered instances from all the rules.
        Returns:
        int

      • getCost

        protected double getCost(BoolVector vars,
                         int vid)
        compute the number I of instances the solution vars+{vid} covers, and return the number (|vars|+1)/(I+1). It is expected that vid is not set in vars.
        Parameters:
        vars -
        vid -
        Returns:

      • isRedundant

        protected boolean isRedundant(int vid,
                              BoolVector cur_vars_sat_insts)
        return true iff the variable vid is redundant in the sense that its presence in the current solution does not allow for any currently non- satisfied instance to be among the "future satisfied ones" by the augmented solution. In other words, a variable is redundant for a solution if all the rules that depend on it cover instances already covered in the current solution.
        Parameters:
        vid - int
        cur_vars_sat_insts - BoolVector
        Returns:
        boolean
